results.title: The Greatest game on earth
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey, Roland Beckett, Australian National Football Council and Melbourne Repertory Film Unit
results.brief_description: Ricky, who has recently arrived in Australia, sees his first game of Australian Rules Football when he follows the boys of his neighbourhood to the Melbourne Cricket Ground where Geelong is playing Collingwood. At first the atmosphere is strange and new, but the boy soon becomes a part of the enthusiastic crowd excited by the fast field play, high punt kicks, snap shots for goal and clever manoeuvres which comprise Australia’s national sport.

results.title: The Greatest gamble
results.brief_description: Christopher Brasher assesses the gambles taken in supporting new inventions and introduces some of the men involved. Includes the trials of the Dr Barnes Wallis swing wing aircraft, and Professor F. C. Williams of Manchester University relives the moment when he saw the way of solving the problems of electronic memory. Other contributors includes Christopher Cockerell who discusses hovercraft, Geoffrey Stockdale on the take-apart ship and Donald Firth on the revolution in cars and machine tools.

results.title: The Greater community animal
results.brief_description: An animated film which examines why the individual has to have his idiosyncrasies and his potentialities processed out of existence in order to be made acceptable to society. Considers individualism, conformism and the compromises which have to be made. American Film Festival Blue Ribbon.

results.title: Great Lakes
results.brief_description: A vast stream of shipping, with millions of tons of varying cargo, moves through the canals and locks of the Great Lakes, passing through the centre of the Canadian Continent. The film shows the booming industrial life of the Great Lakes region - steel production, pulp manufacture, ship-building, grain storage, and the workings of the great lock and canal systems.

results.title: Great Grandmother
results.creator_credit: Lorna Rasmussen, John Taylor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film presents four women, still living, who represent the social position of women in the early wast. Their stores are combined with stills, archival footage, material from publications of the time, diaries, and personal papers. The film was shot in some of the ‘living museums’ of Alberta.

results.title: The Great game
results.brief_description: Association football in Britain, how it is played, the crowds it draws, and what it means to the players and spectators. The game is traced in its various forms from school soccer to first class professional play. Includes scenes photographed at the 1944 Cup Final at which Bolton defeated Chelsea.

results.title: Gravity waves
results.brief_description: Uses animation to explore important work in the search for gravity waves and in design and construction of equipment to measure this subtle force. Includes an interview with Dr. Joseph Weber, a pioneer in gravity wave detection.

results.title: The Grand
results.brief_description: Describes the work done by people of various backgrounds for conservation on the Grand River Watershed in Ontario, Canada. Also gives the background to the work and explains various methods of conservation used in the watershed area.

results.title: Goods traffic for Europe
results.brief_description: Every day some 15,000 goods trains transport their freights to and from the national and international markets contributing to the supply of thousands of European towns. In addition 14,000 passenger trains travel 600,000 miles daily carrying approximately 44 million people.

results.title: A Good beginning
results.creator_credit: Modern Management Films and Norwood Studios
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the right way to induct and train employees on new jobs. Seen through the eyes of a young girl hired to learn a data processing card-punch operation. Compares correct techniques with wrong techniques. Reminds supervisors of the need to relieve tensions in the new employee before useful training can begin.
